question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Let A denote the matrix

\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 & -2 \\ 1 & -2 & 3\\ 4 & -2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]

Find a basis for the column space of A.
sols:
The column space of A is : R(A) = span $\begin{bmatrix}
3\\ 
1\\ 
4
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
-2\\ 
-2
\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}
-2\\ 
3\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$

The vectors spanning column space of A form a basis if they are linearly
independent to one another. We can check this by determining the
nullspace of A N(A). $A\vec{x} = \vec{0}$ If they are linearly
independent, the only solution to the above equation is $\vec{x} = 0$ We
can start by reduced row echelon the matrix A $\begin{bmatrix}
3&0&-2\\ 
1&-2&3\\ 
4&-2&1 
\end{bmatrix}\xrightarrow[R2\rightarrow R1-3R2]{R4-4R2} \begin{bmatrix}
1& 0 &\frac{-2}{3} \\ 
0&6 &-11 \\ 
0&6 &-11 
\end{bmatrix}\xrightarrow[R3 \rightarrow R3 - R2 ]{R2 \rightarrow R2/6}\begin{bmatrix}
1 &0 & \frac{-2}{3}\\ 
0& 1& \frac{-11}{6}\\ 
0& 0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}$ All pivot columns in row echelon form are linearly
independent columns. From above, we can see only column 1 and 2 are
linearly independent. This means column 3 can be written in terms of
column 1 and 2. $\begin{bmatrix}
x1\\ 
x2\\ 
x3
\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}\frac{2}{3}\\ 
\frac{11}{6}\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$ Therefore the columns in the A that corresponds to the
pivot columns of the reduced echelon form is $\begin{bmatrix}
3\\ 
1\\ 
4
\end{bmatrix}$ and $\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
-2\\ 
-2
\end{bmatrix}$. Therefore the basis of the column space of matrix A is
$\begin{bmatrix}
3\\ 
1\\ 
4
\end{bmatrix}$ and $\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
-2\\ 
-2
\end{bmatrix}$.
